Through systematic literature review, the researcher developed a questionnaire to survey teachers’ leadership and instructional competencies. The researcher surveyed 402 full-time teachers from three private high schools in Henan Province. The study found that 1) teachers' instructional competencies at the private high schools of Henan Province, in China, were at the moderate level. 2) Teachers’ instructional competency level was also at the “moderate” level. 3) There is a significant positive correlation between teacher leadership and instructional competencies. 4) Teacher leadership has a measurable impact on instructional competencies. 5) The developed teacher leadership model could help improve teachers’ instructional competencies in private high schools in Henan Province. The researchers Lecturer, Doctor of Education Program in Educational Administration, Graduate School, Stamford International University, Bangkok, Thailand Research interests: education, teaching, students’ motivation discussed each finding and recommended schools that can foster continuous professional growth among their educators, resulting in tangible improvements in instructional quality. Teaching is a complex cognitive skill that focuses on knowledge, ways of constructive planning, and conducting effective lessons that impart knowledge and content in the best possible ways (Day, 2004). Teacher leadership plays an important role in ensuring the development of skills essential for good teaching and learning that are apt to the type of school, its environment, climate, and culture. Teacher leadership is considered one of the core practices of successful school change because teachers are critical in the teaching process (Huang, 2016). To truly make teachers participate in school reform and development, it is necessary to change teachers' traditional role as passive followers and let them assume the professional responsibilities they deserve (Li et al., 2013). Previous studies showed that teachers are the foundation of the education system. Teacher leaders are significant in the teaching workforce as role models for novice teachers, leading to better school outcomes (Zhou & McLaren, 2021). Teacher leaders are agents of change, and this role should be nurtured and explored so that teachers can lead initiatives, challenge the status quo in schools, and pursue excellence in teaching and learning (Grant et al., 2010). Pigozzi (2008) also stated that quality teachers and their instructional competencies meant a lot to increasing school productivity; the quality of the teachers, with their instructional competencies, may be able to engage more students in meaningful teaching and learning practices. The key to standardizing the quality education system is relying on the teachers’ competencies (Jyoti & Sharma, 2009). China's educational reform and the internationalization of educational ideas have been progressing. The outline of China’s National Plan for Medium and Long-term Educational Reform and Development 2010-2020 mentioned that the teachers who can play the part of leaders in the school are expected to be exemplary and radiating. Moreover, the Professional Competency Standards for High School by the Ministry of Education of the People’s Republic of China in 2021 show the call for developing teacher leadership in school. Simultaneously, to enhance the high-quality balance of education in China, teacher leadership has emerged as the primary trend of education reform, a collaborative effort involving multiple forces (Weng, 2016). Therefore, it is essential to fully trust the professionalism of teachers, make full use of their leading role in education reform, develop a cadre of willingness and ability to engage in change activities, and influence other teachers (Ye & Zhu, 2018).

In China, the role of teachers leading does not get enough attention yet, and the sense that teachers can become leaders is vague. Therefore, if teachers want to play a leadership or management role, they first need to be promoted to a formal leadership position, resulting in the loss of excellent front-line teachers (Jin, 2007; Lou, 2015). At the same time, teachers who take a formal leadership role are considered superior to other teachers. Consequently, teacher leaders, such as backbone teachers, hold a status that is unequal to other teachers. They have a mentoring relationship with colleagues, in which teacher leaders are "experts," and others are "inexperienced teachers”. Teacher leadership is about working together to solve problems based on shared interests, not a mentoring relationship (Lou, 2015). Teachers’ complicated role in China's schools is unconscious, and teachers lack conscious leadership concepts. Their leadership among other teachers is unconscious and invisible. Those teachers impact others but do not realize this (Wang & Wang, 2020; Su, 2020). Teacher leaders need to help teachers balance the relationship among colleagues and leaders and maintain a harmonious atmosphere in school (Li et al., 2013). As a result, some teachers are reluctant to take a leadership role to avoid conflict with colleagues, leading to a breakdown of rapport with colleagues (Jin, 2007; Ma, 2013). In a nutshell, the primary factors impeding teacher leadership in China include principals' incorrect leadership style, competitive school tasks, traditional culture, hierarchical systems, the absence of an ideal teacher leadership system, the principal's lack of support for teacher leadership, and factors specific to teachers themselves (Jin, 2007). Under the current development of teacher leadership in China, the backbone teacher is the only official teacher leader (Wang & Wang, 2020).

These three private schools are selected as representatives of three main regions of Henan Province, as well as the top leading private schools. We distributed the questionnaires by email directly to each school from the first semester to the end of the second semester in early 2024. A total of 402 full-time teachers were surveyed; the researcher received 89% of valid questionnaires from the 358 teachers, and the related data were put into the data analysis. After the data collection, the researcher also recorded and processed the data with the assistance of the school administrator. The questionnaire developed by the researcher in this study was named the Questionnaire on Teacher Leadership and Instructional Competencies at Private High Schools in Henan Province of China. 2) The second part of the questionnaire is teacher leadership. This part of the questionnaire was based on the Teacher Leadership Standards Model and then adapted to the actual situation of the targeted Chinese schools in the Henan region for the study. 3) The third part of the questionnaire was to assess the instructional competencies of teachers at the private high schools in the Henan Province of China. Research objective three: to explore the relationship and impact between teacher leadership and their instructional competencies at the private high schools in Henan province Findings from Pearson's correlation coefficient analysis showed that the seven areas of teachers' leadership perception and the five areas of their instructional competencies were all strongly linked. Most of the correlations had moderate-to- high positive associations. In general, the overall teachers’ leadership was highly correlated with the five dimensions of their instructional competencies, as shown that all aspects are strongly positively correlated with the overall relevance. As the detailed p-values and Pearson correlation coefficient results showed, among different domains and dimensions, ACKS was highly related to PAD, FSL was highly related to ASP, DLS was highly related to PPL, ECLE was highly related to CFC, and RTP was highly related to AUR; all these highly correlated factors would be considered to use in the model development process. The regression analysis showed that the leadership domains of teachers had a strong relationship with the teaching competencies dimensions at private high schools in Henan Province, China. As the B scores and P value showed, the dimensions of FFC impacted ECLE the most (p=.004, B=.216), the dimension of AUR impacted RTP the most (p=.004, B=390), the dimension of PPL impacted the DLS the most (p=000, B=.328), the dimension of FII impacted ESL (p=000, B=.382), the dimension of PAD impacted ACKS (p=.007, B=.273), the dimension of CFC impacted ACKS the most (p=000, B=.485), the dimension of ASP impacted ESL the most (p=.004, B=.20), and overall, the teachers’ leadership impacted all the domains of their instructional competencies, including ACKS, FSL, DLS, ECLE, and RTP.

In conclusion, the correlation and regression analysis demonstrated a significant relationship between the leadership dimensions of teachers and their instructional competencies. The main quantitative results from the correlation and regression analyses, along with the descriptive results of teachers' leadership and teaching skills, were used to come up with a proposed model. The researcher also submitted the model to nine experts for their review and validation. Absorbing all the essence of the experts’ suggestion, this researcher also revised the teachers’ leadership model for enhancing teachers’ instructional competencies at the private high schools in Henan Province of China. Step 1: Starting from activities of cultivating DLS (Developing Leadership Skills), through the focus on PPL (Promoting Professional Learning) and FII (Facilitating Instructional Improvement). Step 2: Then turn to improve ECLE (Establishing a Conducive Learning Environment) through the focus on FCC (Fostering a Collaborative Culture) and CFC (Collaborating with Families and Communities). Step 3: Follow by increasing RTP (Reflection of Teaching Practices) through the focus on CFC (Collaborating with Families and Communities) and AUR (Assessing and Using Research). Step 4: Transform to maintain ACKS (Acquisition of content knowledge and skills) through the continuous focus on PAD (Promoting the Assessment and Data). Step 5: Last but not least, it must be back to FSL (Facilitation of Student Learning), based on the focus of ASP (Advocating for Student and Profession) and FII (Facilitating Instructional Improvement). A strong positive correlation was identified between teacher leadership and instructional competencies. Teachers with better leadership abilities tended to demonstrate higher instructional competencies. Leadership practices such as mutual communication and collaboration, as modeled in group discussions and moral education case studies, fostered a culture of shared responsibility and higher performance standards among teachers. The significant positive correlation between teacher leadership and instructional competencies is well-documented in educational research. Instructional leadership is a fundamental component of teacher leadership, encompassing the ability to lead in instructional practice beyond mere content delivery. This includes coaching, mentoring, and fostering collaborative relationships, all of which enhance instructional competencies, as confirmed by the Teacher Leadership Institute. A study that looked at the link between school leaders' instructional leadership and teachers' functional competency also found a very strong one. This means that teachers with higher levels of competency are likely to have effective instructional leadership. The significant correlation between teacher leadership and instructional competencies aligns with theoretical models that underscore their interdependence. Teacher leadership was found to have a direct and measurable impact on instructional competencies. Teachers who embraced leadership roles, such as those in the expert group tasked with observing and selecting top-quality courses, exhibited enhanced competencies in their own classrooms. The direct impact of teacher leadership on instructional competencies is supported by theoretical frameworks that emphasize the role of leadership in educational settings. Competencies for teacher instructional leadership include coaching, mentoring, and building collaborative relationships, which directly influence teaching practices. The National Education Association (NEA) also says that teacher leaders can work with administrators and other important people to improve the quality of teaching. This shows how teacher leadership can completely change how teachers teach. Zhenghang Experimental High School's initiative, including leadership workshops and peer observations, mirrors research findings that structured leadership opportunities lead to improved instructional competencies. The significant improvement in instructional competencies following the implementation of a teacher leadership model is consistent with findings from previous studies. The Teacher Leadership Institute (TLI) emphasized that leadership in instructional practice involves more than content delivery; it includes guiding peers, leading professional development, and advocating effective instructional strategies. Additionally, research has shown that instructional leadership promotes teacher leadership by improving teaching practices across the school, leading to enhanced instructional competencies. The improvement in teachers’ instructional competencies following the implementation of a teacher-led model aligns with empirical studies emphasizing the importance of leadership models.

The findings are consistent with prior research and theoretical frameworks, emphasizing the critical role of teacher leadership in enhancing instructional competencies. Building on transformational leadership theory, distributed leadership models, and empirical evidence, schools should continue investing in leadership development programs.
